export.notes: Tintype is a negative image produced on a thin iron plate, viewed as positive due to an undercoationg of black Japan varnish. Also called melainotype. Introduced in 1856. Peak years: 1860-1863.
export.title: Beatrice and Bernadette

export.title: Sunday Afternoon

export.appnotes: This photograph is in good condition with very little damage to the emulsion side. The photo is glued to a backing material that shows some water stains along the lower edge. The photo is very grainy and printed on poor quality paper. The value of this photograph is in its Civil War Era provenance and the Union Revenue Stamp on the back.
export.condnotes: This photograph is in good condition with very little damage to the emulsion side. The photo is glued to a backing material that shows some water stains along the lower edge. The photo is very grainy and printed on poor quality paper.
export.copyright: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum without restriction.
export.credit: In memory of Rev. John L. McWilliams
export.descrip:
Portrait of husband and wife with baby. They are seated on backless stools. The woman holds a very young infant on her lap. The baby is dressed in a white gown. This carte-de-visite has a hand-cancelled Civil War revenue stamp on the reverse side.
From August 1964 to August 1866 the U.S. government instituted a law requiring that a tax stamp be attached to the backs of certain types of photograph and that it be cancelled by the selling establishment at the time of sale. The 2 cent revenue stamp was required for images costing less than 25 cents each. The blue 2 cent "playing cards" stamp was used during the summer of 1866. Images with this stamp can be specifically dated to the summer of that year.
The stamp is hand-cancelled with the initials, H E C. and dated Jan 7.
export.frame: 4" x 2.5" Photograph attached to thin cardboard.
export.maintnote: 07/13/2000 - Examined and placed in mylar sleeve. MLP 06/29/2002 - Examined. No defects observed. JT
export.people: Carter, John L. Carter, Honoria Page Carter, Lisbeth Anne
export.title: Captain Carter and Family

export.appnotes: Leo Feldstein is the owner of the Incunabula & Ephemera Shoppe located in Philadelphia, PA. The shop specialized in antique documents and photographs. He is a member of the International Association of Antique Appraisers (IAAA).

The tintype is held in place by a paper backing. The name "Armin" is written in pencil on the back.

export.caption: Joh L. McWilliams & son
export.copyright: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum without restriction.
export.credit: In memory of Rev. John L. McWilliams
export.descrip: Reverend John L. McWilliams as a young man. He is holding his son, John Jr.. He is seated on a settee with a low back and rolled arms. The baby boy is seated on the arm of the settee with the man's arm around him.
export.notes:
Note: Boy children usually wore dresses until school age. This practice continued up until about 1900. Boy's dresses can often be distinguished by being made of plaid fabric with a dropped waste.
For more information on children's fashion, See: The Child in Fashion 1750-1920. Harris,Kristina. Schiffer Publishing Ltd. Atglen, PA. 1999.
export.people: McWilliams, John Lawrence McWilliams, John L. Jr.
export.title: Reverend McWilliams and Little Jack

export.appnotes: Leo Feldstein is the owner of the Incunabula & Ephemera Shoppe located in Philadelphia, PA. The shop specialized in antique documents and photographs. He is a member of the International Association of Antique Appraisers (IAAA).

export.credit: In memory of Rev. John L. McWilliams
export.descrip: Formal portrait of Perry Clayton. He is resting one arm on a table with a book. He is dressed in a suit with only the top button closed showing his watch chain. This photograph was taken when he graduated from Medical School at Madison, WI at the young age of 17. The watch and chain were a graduation gift from his father, John Paul Clayton.
export.frame: 6 1/2" x 4" Black card with photographer name at bottom in gold
export.pubnotes: Zablonski, Robert A., Prominent Men of Medicine, University Press. Madison, WI. 1925. (p.255).
export.sterms: Carter Family McWilliams Family Clayton Family
export.title: Dr. Perry Clayton

export.caption: Family portrait
export.condnotes: 05/05/2001 Examined. Found in excellent condition. MLP
export.copyright: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum without restriction.
export.credit: In memory of Ebenezer J. Carter b.1817 - d.1876.
export.descrip: Photograph of nine people. The four adults are seated in the front row and five children are standing behind them (left to right - Patricia, Margaret, Anne Marie, Jennie, John Paul, Jr.). The two adults in the middle are John and Pauline Clayton, the parents of all five children. Seated to the left of John Clayton is his cousin, Perry Clayton. Seated to the right of Pauline is her brother, Horace Gray. The photo was taken at the high school graduation party held in honor of Margaret Clayton.
export.dimnotes: This photograph came with a tinplate frame with a lithographed wood-grain design. The frame was removed and is stored separately. See #2000.1.18
export.notes: The Carter and Clayton families were important pioneers in the establishment of Pastville and Perfectown. They were prominent citizens throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries. Pauline Carter Fisk was a founding member of the PastPerfect Museum in 1989.
export.people: Clayton, Patricia Clayton, Margaret "Peg" Clayton, Anne Marie Clayton, Jennie Clayton, John Paul Jr. Clayton, Perry Clayton, John Paul Sr. Clayton, Pauline Gray Gray, Horace W.
export.provenance: This photograph was found in the personal effects of Margaret Clayton Morgan at her death in 1951. It became the property of Rose Ellen Carter, Margaret Clayton's cousin. The photo came into possession of the PastPerfect Museum by deed of gift in 2000.
export.pubnotes: See: Carter, Rose Ellen. The Carters and the Claytons: Our Family Story. Vanity Press. 1985.
export.title: Peg's Graduation

export.copyright: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum without restriction.
export.credit: In memory of my mother, Rosemary Hollis Kittridge
export.descrip: Photo postcard of a young girl. The card has an illustration of a bunch of lilacs with a small oval opening for the photograph and the words "Regards From" written in glue and glitter. The oval opening is 3 cm x 2.2 cm. The photo is attached to the card by pasting a paper backing over the entire back of the card. The verso of the card has a handwritten message, "Greetings from Coney Island. Your friend, Betty". The card is addressed to Peg Carter.
export.title: Regards From Betty

export.credit: For my father, Clair Norton Hanley
export.descrip:
Crew of the Old "01" U.S.S. PC (C) 1601. Known to the crew as the P.I.B. (Pig Iron Bastard).
PC-1601 (USS Fierce) PC-1568 class Submarine Chaser (ex Adroit class Minesweeper): Displacement: 450 tons Length: 173'8" Beam: 23' Draft: 11'7" Speed: 17 knots Armament: 1 3"/50, 1 40mm Complement: 105 Alco diesel engine, twin screws, 1,440 shaft hp. Built at Nashville Bridge and commissioned as AM-97 1943 Converted to Sub Chaser (PC-1601) 1944
export.legal: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum without restriction.
export.provenance: The photographer of these WWII Pacific Theater photographs is Claire Norton Hanley. Claire Hanley was a young naval officer during WWII. He served on the ship as Lieut. (jg) in the Pacific Theater. His ship, the USS Fierce, participated in major naval operations at the end of WWII including the invasions at Okinawa and Akashima Japan and Leyte and Luzon in the Philipines.
export.subjects: Naval operations Naval warfare Naval personnel
export.tempreason: Pulled for World War II Exhibit
export.title: Crew of the P.I.B.

There are a number of small (less than 1 mm) spots that are presumed to be foxing. Yellowing is evident over the entire image. Because of the vintage of the image as well as the provenance and subject matter (WWII ship) a relatively high value is placed on the item.
export.caption: USS Fierce
export.creator: Hanley, Clair N.
export.credit: For my father, Clair Norton Hanley
export.descrip:
The U.S.S. PC (C) 1601 coming into an unidentified port. This ship was known to its crew as the P.I.B. (Pig Iron Bastard).
PC-1601 (USS Fierce) PC-1568 class Submarine Chaser (ex Adroit class Minesweeper): Displacement: 450 tons Length: 173'8" Beam: 23' Draft: 11'7" Speed: 17 knots Armament: 1 3"/50, 1 40mm Complement: 105 Alco diesel engine, twin screws, 1,440 shaft hp. Built at Nashville Bridge and commissioned as AM-97 1943 Converted to Sub Chaser (PC-1601) 1944
export.notes: Invasion of Luzon Naval Historical Center --Southwest Pacific Force operations against Luzon were directly supported by Seventh Fleet escort carriers in Task Group 77.4 (Rear Admiral C. T. Durgin) and indirectly by the fast carriers in Task Force 38 (Vice Admiral J. S. McCain) of Third Fleet and Central Pacific Forces. Task Group 77.4, with 17 escort carriers, covered the approach of the Luzon Attack Force against serious enemy air opposition from Kamikaze pilots which sank Ommaney Bay (4 Jan), and damaged several ships including escort carriers Manila Bay and Savo Island (5 Jan). It conducted preliminary strikes in the assault area (7-9 Jan), covered the landings in Lingayen Gulf (9 Jan), and supported the inland advance of troops ashore (9-17 Jan). Among the ships damaged by Kamikaze pilots opposing the landings were the escort carriers Kadashan Bay and Kitkun Bay (8 Jan), and Salamaua (13 Jan). Task Force 38, with seven heavy and four light carriers in three groups and one heavy and one light carrier in a night group, and accompanied by a Replenishment Group with one hunter-killer and seven escort carriers, concentrated on the destruction of enemy air power and air installations in surrounding areas. In spite of almost continuous bad weather which hampered flight operations during the entire month, this force launched offensive strikes on Formosa and the Ryukyus (3-4 Jan), a 2-day attack on Luzon (6-7 Jan) and on fields in the Formosa-Pescadores-Ryukyus area (9 Jan), destroying over 100 enemy aircraft and sinking 40,000 tons of merchant and small combatant ships in 1 week of preliminary action. During the night (9-10 Jan) Task Force 38 made a high-speed run through Luzon Strait followed by the Replenishment Group which passed through Balintang Channel, for Operations in the South China Sea (9-20 Jan). Strikes (12 Jan), over 420 miles of the Indo-China coast, reached south to Saigon and caught ships in the harbor and in coastal convoys with devastating results, sinking 12 tankers, 20 passenger and cargo vessels and numerous small combatant ships, totalling 149,000 tons. Moving northward to evade a typhoon, the force hit targets at Hong Kong, the China Coast, and Formosa (15 Jan) and next day concentrated on the Hong Kong area damaging enemy shore installations and sinking another 62,000 tons of shipping. As inclement weather persisted, the force left the South China Sea with an after dark run through Balintang Channel (20 Jan) and hit Formosa, the Pescadores, and Okinawa against enemy air opposition which damaged the Ticonderoga and Langley (20 Jan) and repeated the attack in the Ryukyus next day to finish off 3 weeks of action with an aerial score of over 600 enemy aircraft destroyed and 325,000 tons of enemy shipping sunk.
export.provenance: The photographer of these WWII Pacific Theater photographs is Claire Norton Hanley. Claire Hanley was a young naval officer during WWII. He served on the ship in the above photograph as Lieut. (jg) in the Pacific Theater. His ship participated in major naval operations at the end of WWII including the invasions at Okinawa and Akashima Japan and Leyte and Luzon in the Philipines.
export.sterms: World War II WWII Hanley Family
export.subjects: World War II Naval warfare Ships
export.title: USS Fierce

export.notes: Invasion of Luzon Naval Historical Center --Southwest Pacific Force operations against Luzon were directly supported by Seventh Fleet escort carriers in Task Group 77.4 (Rear Admiral C. T. Durgin) and indirectly by the fast carriers in Task Force 38 (Vice Admiral J. S. McCain) of Third Fleet and Central Pacific Forces. Task Group 77.4, with 17 escort carriers, covered the approach of the Luzon Attack Force against serious enemy air opposition from Kamikaze pilots which sank Ommaney Bay (4 Jan), and damaged several ships including escort carriers Manila Bay and Savo Island (5 Jan). It conducted preliminary strikes in the assault area (7-9 Jan), covered the landings in Lingayen Gulf (9 Jan), and supported the inland advance of troops ashore (9-17 Jan). Among the ships damaged by Kamikaze pilots opposing the landings were the escort carriers Kadashan Bay and Kitkun Bay (8 Jan), and Salamaua (13 Jan). Task Force 38, with seven heavy and four light carriers in three groups and one heavy and one light carrier in a night group, and accompanied by a Replenishment Group with one hunter-killer and seven escort carriers, concentrated on the destruction of enemy air power and air installations in surrounding areas. In spite of almost continuous bad weather which hampered flight operations during the entire month, this force launched offensive strikes on Formosa and the Ryukyus (3-4 Jan), a 2-day attack on Luzon (6-7 Jan) and on fields in the Formosa-Pescadores-Ryukyus area (9 Jan), destroying over 100 enemy aircraft and sinking 40,000 tons of merchant and small combatant ships in 1 week of preliminary action. During the night (9-10 Jan) Task Force 38 made a high-speed run through Luzon Strait followed by the Replenishment Group which passed through Balintang Channel, for Operations in the South China Sea (9-20 Jan). Strikes (12 Jan), over 420 miles of the Indo-China coast, reached south to Saigon and caught ships in the harbor and in coastal convoys with devastating results, sinking 12 tankers, 20 passenger and cargo vessels and numerous small combatant ships, totalling 149,000 tons. Moving northward to evade a typhoon, the force hit targets at Hong Kong, the China Coast, and Formosa (15 Jan) and next day concentrated on the Hong Kong area damaging enemy shore installations and sinking another 62,000 tons of shipping. As inclement weather persisted, the force left the South China Sea with an after dark run through Balintang Channel (20 Jan) and hit Formosa, the Pescadores, and Okinawa against enemy air opposition which damaged the Ticonderoga and Langley (20 Jan) and repeated the attack in the Ryukyus next day to finish off 3 weeks of action with an aerial score of over 600 enemy aircraft destroyed and 325,000 tons of enemy shipping sunk.
export.provenance: This WWII Pacific Theater photograph was taken by Claire Norton Hanley. Claire Hanley was a young naval officer. His ship participated in major naval operations at the end of WWII including the invasions at Okinawa and Akashima, Japan and Leyte and Luzon in the Philipines.
export.sterms: Hanley Family World War II WWII

export.appnotes: Cabinet card photos are quite common. However, the subject, an African-American child, makes this a rare photograph and adds to its value.
export.caption: Viola Rose
export.condnotes: This cabinet card is in good condition. The image is printed on glossy paper which exhibits some scratches to the glossy surface.
export.copyright: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum.
export.creator: Gaites, Hillman T.
export.credit: In memory of Hannah B. Washington.
export.descrip: Cabinet card portrait of Viola Rose Washington taken during a trip to Illinois to visit relatives. The Washington Family was a prominent African-American family in Chester County from the late 18th century to the present.
export.maintnote: 07/06/2004 - Examined and placed in mylar sleeve.
export.title: Viola Rose

export.copyright: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum.
export.descrip: Sepia-toned cabinet card of small boy. The boy is wearing a striped sailor suit and standing on a chair. His blond hair is arranged in curls.
export.title: Phillip Wright Adams, age 6

export.caption: Mary Cullen Auden
export.copyright: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum.
export.creator: Edwards, A. R.
export.descrip: Carte-de-visite portrait of Mary Cullen Auden taken in London in 1974. Mary Cullen Auden arrived in Perfectown, PA in 1885. She worked as a domestic in the home of Captain Horace B. Carter.
export.title: Mary Cullen Auden

export.caption: Babbitt Home
export.condnotes: Slight scratch on print Upper Right Quadrant Corners of mounting cardstock are bent and frayed.
export.copyright: All rights belong to PastPerfect Museum
export.creator: Unknown
export.credit: In memory of my grandfather, Patrick Carter Babbitt
export.descrip: Two story white clapboard house with white fence. Two newly planted trees outside the fence are surrounded by pickets. There is a water storage tank in the background as well as a church and a small barn or shed. There are four people on the upper balcony.
export.dimnotes: Overall dimensions including cardstock mount: 9" x 6"
export.legal: All copyrights belong to the PastPerfect Museum.
export.provenance: Item has been in the possession of the Babbitt Family since it was taken. Acquired by Deed of Gift by PastPerfect Museum 2009.
export.subjects: Architecture Homes Churches Barns Water tanks
export.title: Babbitt House

export.caption: Wedding Day
export.condnotes: Photograph is in excellent condition. No tears, stains, or foxing. No evidence of fading or other deterioration.
export.creator: Brantnor, Octavius
export.descrip: This photograph depicts Ethel (Gregory) and Neil Packwood, Sr. on their wedding day, March 21, 1902.
export.event: Ehtel and Neil Packwood Sr. Wedding
export.maintnote: Examine photograph and make sure mylar sleeve is in good condition.
export.people: Packwood, Ethel Gregory Packwood, Neil Sr.
export.title: Ehtel and Neil Packwood Sr. Wedding

export.credit: In memory of my grandfather, Thomas Greene, who loved old photographs.
export.descrip:
Portrait of a young woman with dark hair parted down the middle with curled bangs. She is wearing a dress with beaded yoke at the neck and on on the outer skirt. Her collar is velvet and she is wearing a lace choker and cameo pin. Her chatelaine has a cross. Her arm is resting on a late 19th century primitive style chair.
Marked on back of card "17356".
export.dimnotes: Adhered to card which is 4 1/4" x 6 1/2".

export.credit: In memory of my grandfather, Thomas Greene, who loved old photographs.
export.descrip:
Portrait of a woman with a Spanish comb. She has leg of mutton sleeves, a high collar, and beading on the bodice of her dress.
Marked on back of card in pencil "40417/Annie Graben".

export.credit: In memory of my grandfather, Thomas Greene, who loved old photographs.
export.descrip:
Portrait of a woman with glasses a curly gray hair. She is wearing a dress with beaded shoulders and large ruffled collar.
Marked on back of card "46165".

export.credit: In memory of my grandfather, Thomas Greene, who loved old photographs.
export.descrip:
Portrait of a man wearing a dark suit. He is sitting in an armchair and is holding a newspaper. The man also has facial hair along both jawbones.
At the bottom of the card printed in metallic gold is the photographers name of Broadbent & Taylor, 914 Chestnut Street. On the back of the card in black print shows the Broadbent & Taylor signature and logos. At the top of the card, there is a handwritten note of Nov 20 1878/ Property of Lawrence Johnson. Two other markings are in pencil "3 00/SUE" and "S0611'.

export.credit: In memory of my grandfather, Thomas Greene, who loved old photographs.
export.descrip:
Portrait of a young man in a suit with a waistcoat and white tie.
Printed on the bottom on the front of the card "Grotecloss/Extra Finish/144 & 146 Market St./Paterson, N.J.".
Printed on back of card "Grotecloss/Photographer/114 & 146 Market Street/Paterson/N.J./Negatives kept - /Copies can be had at any time." Also an illustration with a lens with a painter's palette, brushes, ribbon and camera on legs. It says "Solar/Phot's/Crayons/ect." in the palette.

export.caption: Harper Triplets
export.condnotes: Overall condition of photo is excellent. No tears or creases. The emulsion layer is in good condition without fading or other deterioration.
export.creator: unknown
export.credit: Donated by the Hartford Family
export.descrip: Photo of the Harper Triplets, 1911. The Harper triplets were the first known set of triplets born in Pastville, Pennsylvania, Born in 1851 the sisters were a sensation throughout the region because of the rarity of triple births. In the photo, the three sisters are seated on the porch of the house believed to belong to Olga. The eldest, Olivia is wearing glasses. Olga is in the middle. On the far right is Octavia who is identifiable because of the head scarf she was known to wear. In the foreground is Olga's granddaughter, Jilly Jean Mortenson.
export.maintnote: Check condition of photograph and condition of mylar sleeve.
export.people: Harper, Octavia Harper, Olga Harper, Olivia
export.title: Harper Twins

export.caption: Parade
export.credit: Donated by the Hartford Family
export.descrip: Stereograph of a parade. Men on horseback in fancy dress uniforms.
export.title: Parade
